comments: OPIM 101 is an introductory course designed to aid familiarity and develop comfort with the use of computers to solve management problems. The course offers a solid foundation in computers and modeling and provides the computer skills essential to Wharton course work and professional endeavors. While OPIM 101 teaches students the technical elements of management software like excel, it also cultivates an understanding of the role of computers in modern organizations. Specific topics include budgeting, analytical modeling, sensitivity analysis, database management, decision analysis, optimization, and simulation. The course structure is made up of one lecture and one recitation with lab exercises per week. No prior background in either computers or operations and information management is expected. Students liked the hands-on element of the lab exercises in recitations. They also stressed that attending recitation was a valuable and effective method of reinforcing the course material. One student affirmed, “OPIM 101 has been the most useful course I’ve taken at Wharton.” Students found Professor Lee’s attention to their questions and concerns fulfilling. They also enjoyed his enthusiasm and ability to stimulate student interest. Many students commented that Professor Lee communicates the subject matter clearly and effectively. One student mentioned, “Professor Lee has a way of explaining things that make even the most abstract concepts understandable.” Some students, however, found that he went through explanations too quickly.Some students were unsatisfied with the grading system of recitation assignments and other assignments. Some found the course material to be challenging and supplied high marks in the course difficulty category.
